title: Dividing Terms
text: Remember, we must start by dividing the first term, $$6x^3$$, by $$3x$$. This gives us $$2x^2$$.
speech: Remember, we must start by dividing the first term,  6 x cubed, , by  3 x . This gives us  2 x squared .
pacedSpeech: Remember, we must start by dividing the first term,   6 x cubed,

title: Multiplying Expressions
text: Now, we must multiply everything in the divisor by $$2x^2$$ and subtract from the original polynomial. This means we subtract $$6x^3-4x^2$$. This cycle of "division" and "multiplication" will continue until the divident is of a lesser degree than the divisor.
speech: Now, we must multiply everything in the divisor by  2 x squared,  and subtract from the original polynomial. This means we subtract  6 x cubed minus 4 x squared . This cycle of "division" and "multiplication" will continue until the divident is of a lesser degree than the divisor.
pacedSpeech: Now, we must multiply everything in the divisor by   2 x squared,
and subtract from the original polynomial. This means we subtract   6 x cubed minus 4 x squared
. This cycle of "division" and "multiplication" will continue until the divident is of a lesser degree than the divisor.

title: Remainder
text: Sometimes, we will be left with a remainder and will not be able to divide any further (when the dividend has a lower degree than the divisor). When this occurs, we write out the answer and add it to the $$\frac{remainder}{divisor}$$.
speech: Sometimes, we will be left with a remainder and will not be able to divide any further (when the dividend has a lower degree than the divisor). When this occurs, we write out the answer and add it to the  remainder over divisor .
pacedSpeech: Sometimes, we will be left with a remainder and will not be able to divide any further (when the dividend has a lower degree than the divisor). When this occurs, we write out the answer and add it to the   remainder over divisor
